1111.content:
"Get back here you coward! You're only purpose in life is to die by my hand! Just give it up, you can't escape!" Accelerator shouted as he chased after a fleeing Misaka clone through the power plant.

Misaka #1095 had foolishly engaged Accelerator in battle with an overconfident attitude. Fighting against Accelerator in a power plant, she thought that her ability to control electricity would give her an easy edge in this fight. The location of the battle should have given her a greater advantage in her fight than the other clones had been given. But instead, it did absolutely nothing to aid her in her battle. Accelerator's vector-change ability allowed him to redirect any attack that she launched against him away harmlessly, and he had easily forced #1095 into a full retreat. It may have been her destiny as one of the clones made specifically for the 'Sisters Project' to be killed by Accelerator, but she was still terrified of dying nonetheless.She was now retreating as fast as she could, but it was pointless in the long run. Accelerator was merely toying with her, and he eventually got bored of this game. He quickly used his vector-shift ability to catapult himself over the clone's head and land directly in front of her.

"Tsk, tsk, tsk... Didn't I tell you that there was no escape? Just accept your fate!"

Accelerator then placed his hand on #1095's stomach, and used his abilities to send her flying in the opposite direction. The helpless Misaka clone was thrown like a rag doll, and she quickly collided with a massive generator behind her, and got tangled up in power wires. Accelerator was now walking slowly toward her, laughing at her futile struggles to untangle herself and escape.

#1095 soon realized that she wouldn't be able to escape in time, and decided to try one last desperate strategy before she was killed. Grabbing one cable in each hand, the Misaka clone began drawing the electric energy from the generator in an attempt to recharge her power. She had only intended to use the energy to amplify one of her own lightning bolts enough to stun her attacker and give her more time to escape, but she was amazed by what began to happen instead. As she continued absorbing the energy, #1095 felt her body beginning to grow!

Within mere seconds, she had almost doubled in size. From her original height of 5'3", Misaka #1095 was now at least 10 feet tall! She was still growing, and she easily snapped through the cables that only moments ago held her captive. Upon reaching a height of 25 feet tall, she turned around and smirked at Accelerator. At her new size, the intimidating boy who was about to kill her earlier looked to be only slightly above 1 foot tall. Needless to say, she couldn't help but find it amusing how pathetic he now looked. Even Accelerator himself was fairly nervous upon seeing his victim's sudden growth spurt, but he wasn't about to show it.

"Well... You sure grew pretty fast. Maybe now you'll be able to pose a decent challenge for me!" Accelerator bluffed. On the inside, he was shaking in his boots.

#1095 simply burst out laughing. She just couldn't believe that this puny little creature was still trying to threaten her given the obvious exchange of power between the two. It amused her to no end that she was cowering in fear from this fool only minutes ago, and now she had him completely at her mercy.

"Oh please, Accelerator... I doubt you have it in you to even try attacking me now!"

Accelerator scowled in anger. As terrified as he was, he wasn't about to let himself be told off by a girl!

"Oh yeah?! Just watch me!"

He then launched himself off of the ground with his powers and aimed a flying kick straight at the Misaka clone's stomach. It connected perfectly, but #1095 didn't even flinch. She simply giggled as Accelerator's valiant attempt at attacking her bounced off harmlessly.

"Jee, little guy... That tickled!"

Accelerator now stood frozen with a look of terror now clearly visible on his face. As he looked up at the devious face of the towering Misaka clone above him, he immediately realized just how helpless he really was.

Finally. After years of research, the Flask Plan was at last coming to fruition. The result of all those years of hard work? A simple formula of green liquid, held within a single test tube that was now hidden in the desk of Sandbox Academy's principal. This formula would change the world. It held the power to turn any human, be they Normal or Special, into a superhuman Abnormal on par with even the great Medaka Kurokami herself! This revolutionary formula would usher in a new age for humanity, and soon everyone on the planet would be able to surpass their limits and do things that they could never have dreamed of.

One girl, knowing of the formula and what it was capable of, resolved to steal it for herself.

On that night, the girl snuck into the principal's office without ever being detected. With incredible ease they broke through the lock that was keeping the principal's desk shut; keeping that formula out of their reach. She stole the formula and then swiftly escaped into the night, leaving not a single trace behind. Her path illuminated by the light of the moon, the thief ran off into the night to begin the execution of her own plan.

Your little sister was born with a disease that left her incredibly weak. Ever since she was born you had helped your parents take care of her. Unfortunately, your parents both died in a car accident soon after your 18th birthday. You had planned to move out and live on your own, but you knew that you couldn't just leave your sister behind. Five years later, you're a 23 year old young man and are living alone with your little sister Sarah. Now she's 16, but her disease keeps her from doing much in the way of physical activities. Without the strength to take care of herself, you appointed yourself as her caretaker to make sure she was able to live a happy life. However, when something strange causes you to shrink down to 6 inches tall, your roles are suddenly reversed. Now you are the helpless one, and to make up for everything you did for her over the years, Sarah has promised to do everything she can to take care of you from now on. Thus, our story begins with you and your sister as you try to maintain the peaceful life that you worked so hard to create.


Characters:

Robert (you): Age 23. Robert is an average young man appearance-wise. He's fairly muscular, but not enough to really stand out from the crowd. He's a caring and selfless person who has dedicated his life to taking care of his little sister and making her happy. Over the years he's worked hard to earn as much money as possible. Combining these earnings with the money that he inherited from his deceased parents, he was easily able to afford a small house and all the necessities. With plenty of money left over, he was planning on retiring from his many jobs so that he could take care of his sister full time. Unfortunately, things didn't quite work out that way.

Sarah (your sister): Age 16. Sarah is a cute girl with a fairly attractive appearance. She's very pretty, but due to her condition she's also very skinny as well, and she is generally a little self conscious about her outward appearance. She was born with a disease that left her incredibly physically weak, and so she hasn't been able to do much by herself since the day she was born. In recent years, however, she has begun to come up with several innovative ways to get things done on her own. Not wanting to burden her brother for her entire life, she began to work hard to become increasingly self sufficient. And it's a good thing she's been learning how to take care of herself, because soon she'll need to be able to take care of her precious brother as well.

Sammy (your nextdoor neighbor): Age 24. Sammy is a mature young woman who lives next door to you and your sister. Much like you, her parents disappeared as well and she was forced to move out with her little sister. Due to the similarities of your circumstances, the two of you instantly hit it off and became close friends. She's very kind and has helped you out greatly on more than one occasion. She's a bit of a tomboy, but she tends to flirt with you every now and then. A bit of a tease, she loves a good prank and once helped Sarah position a bucket of water over your bedroom door on April Fool's day. You've known her ever since you moved in next to her, and over the course of five years she has become something of an elder sister figure to both you and Sarah. She would gladly do anything she could to help you and Sarah if you ever needed it.

Maya (Sammy's little sister): Age 8. Maya is a hyperactive little girl with a deep admiration for Sarah. Never being able to hold still herself, she was amazed when she met your sister and saw how calm she was. After meeting Sarah when she was only three years old, Maya began to look up to her and aspired to become like her. The way she used her creative mind to make up for her weakness was a major inspiration to young Maya. Although she's still just as hyper as ever, she's recently started taking after Sarah by creating all sorts of gizmos and gadgets to assist her own older sister's daily life. Unknown to you, while your sister is amazingly smart for a girl her age, her intellect pales in comparison to Maya's. Maya is nothing short of a child genius, and her most recent creation was actually the cause of your sudden shrinking.


Rules:

1. No male characters other than you.
2. Keep the characters in character. Sarah isn't going to take advantage of you once you shrink, she's going to try and help you.
3. No single sentence chapters.

This is a giantess story about a world in which humans and dragons have been at war for generations. The dragons were massive and powerful, but they lacked intelligence. Since they acted only on instinct, humanity had been able to hold their own against them. One day, however, a massive dragon with human-like intelligence arises and unifies the dragons under her rule. Now that the dragons have access to the one thing that the humans could use as an advantage over them, what exactly will become of the human race?

Some information about the races and characters in this story

Humans: Humans are as you would expect them to be. They are exactly as they are in real life, relying on their superior intelligence to overcome adversaries who would otherwise outclass them in every way. In the war against dragons, humans have been able to hold their own by setting traps and engaging a single dragon with many well organized soldiers acting in unison.

Dragons: The dragons in this story are different form normal dragons. They are an entirely female race and have a mostly humanoid form. They possess powerful wings and tails, and their bodies are coated in thick scales that act as a natural armor to protect them from all but the sharpest of blades. Although they look fairly similar to humans, they have very little in the way of intelligence. They act almost entirely on instinct, and humans are their favorite prey. The average height of a dragon is 25 feet tall, with the tallest capping at around 30. In addition to their massive size and monstrous strength, they also possess the ability to breath fire freely. In addition to their low intelligence, they have difficulties dealing with multiple fast moving targets simultaneously, and thus a large organized group attacking in unison would have an advantage and be able to defeat one of them.

Exedra: The dragon queen. Exedra appeared out of nowhere one day, and her arrival signaled a major turning point in the war between humans and dragons. Unlike most dragons, Exedra is not driven by instinct. She has intelligence beyond even most humans, and is able to command the dragons at will. Even compared to other dragons, Exedra is truly massive, towering at an enormous 150 feet tall. In addition to all of her power and intellect, Exedra is immortal, never aging no matter how much time passes. She may even have access to some kind of magical powers. Little is known about her origins.

1. Male dragons don't exist.

Humans and dragons had been at war for thousands of years. While humans are smaller and weaker in most aspects, they held one key advantage over their dragon adversaries. The dragons were like animals, driven only by instinct and their desire to feed on humans. As such, up until that fateful day, it had been possible to fend them off using human ingenuity to outsmart and overcome them.

However, one day all of that changed. Suddenly and without warning, the dragons begin to unify. Where in the past they would attack at random and without any semblance of a plan, now working together systematically to tear apart any weak points in the humans' defenses. It was as if someone were giving them commands and instructing them on how to successfully capture their prey.

Soon it was revealed that this was indeed the case. A massive dragon, towering over all others in the same way they towered over humans, announced herself to humanity. She called herself Exedra the Dragon Queen, and unlike all other dragons before her she seemed to have the same level of intelligence as humans did. Under her command, the dragons who had once been a disorganized mob quickly became an unified force and drove humanity to the brink of extinction.

Just when it seemed that the dragons would wipe the human race off of the face of the earth once and for all, Exedra issued an ultimatum. Surrender and be enslaved by the dragons, or become extinct as the dragons raze them to the ground. The humans, left without any other option, chose to surrender to Exedra. That moment signaled the end of an era, and the beginning of another. Humans no longer ruled the world, now it was the dragons who were in control.

Several generations passed since then. While the lives of all of the dragons and humans from the time of that war had long since been lost to the passage of time, Exedra alone still lived. Since the day she first appeared, she never once aged. Humans had hoped that she would one day die, and that the dragons would lose their sense of order along with her. Unfortunately for them, this would never happen. Not only was Exedra immortal, her influence had changed the dragons' very nature. Each passing generation of dragons grew increasingly smarter, until the day came when all dragons shared Exedra's monumental wisdom.

It was clear that humanity would never again exist for any purpose beyond serving the dragons. Many villages existed for the sole purpose of breeding humans as food for the dragons. Others for training humans to become properly submissive slaves for their dragon mistresses. Some villages were built around massive colosseums, where humans would fight to the death against their own kin for the dragons' amusement. There was great variety among the many human villages that existed, but they all had one thing in common. They were enslaved. They only existed because the dragons allowed them to exist, and if they failed to satisfy their owners, they would be burned to the ground or trampled underfoot without a second thought.

This was the role of humanity in the new world. Dragons had taken over and built up a society of their own over the ashes of the fallen humans. Exedra was the supreme authority in the world who was worshiped as a goddess by both humans and dragons alike.

F Prefacture, F City was once a wonderful, bustling metropolis, with nice green spaces, and buildings far enough apart for someone between 50 and 250 feet to walk between without much difficulty. Yet, due to the recent economic crisis that had struck Japan, living conditions were poor. Innocent people found themselves violently tossed between jobs, unable to keep a steady income, and desiring to crush the upper class beneath their feet.

Thus, the secret ideological organization, ACROSS, was born. An underground revolutionary group, lead by the charming and charismatic Lord Il Palazzo, they swore to bring the world to justice, and end all forms of war and inequality. But for now, since the group consisted of four members- said leader, Excel, Hyatt, and Menchi- they'd lower their goalposts. First, conquer the city. The rest would come naturally.

And, despite her optimistic devotion, Excel was stuck on a limited budget. So, there were days where her fridge was empty. On those days, Menchi, her pet dog, doubled as a living pack of emergency rations.

"Come on, Menchi! We all have to make sacrifices for the good of the city! I've done my part, Hyatt's done hers- it's your turn! It won't be so bad, I swear!"

Her bare feet slammed against the wood floorboards as she dashed forward, reaching out for the horrified canine. She was clad in ACROSS' uniform, showing off her cleavage and legs. How can this nubile young woman possibly eat, take out her financial and romantic frustrations, and improve the state of the city?"

And so came a plot device. Of course, the actual method a girl grows in these stories isn't usually all that important- the result matters, not what started it. The Puchuus, an alien race, had been working on a growth ray to wage war on humanity, and dropped it nearby. The Great Will of the Macrocosm took pity on the woman, and blessed her with size for her loyalty to ACROSS. Nuclear waste was dumped right onto Excel. Poemi, the magical girl, misfired a growth spell. Some rare growth hormone went into effect. An afro'ed man drugged her with growth liquid, or tossed a growth potion down her throat. Something like that. Take your pick.

Soon, her shoulders emerged from the ceiling, followed by her chest, bouncing a little. Wide-eyed, she gazed down, panicking. Stepping out carefully, gazing as her careless boots caused unspeakable property damage, she found herself at loss for words for a moment. Dumbly, she watched as faceless crowds stared towards her towering form, shocked, unmoving, practically begging to be snuffed out violently.

The strength of her shout tossed half of the crowd away- but it was her rapid, panicked movements that did the most destruction, as she dashed this way and that, tearing her hair out. People below ran in terror as her panic attack destroyed their homes.

"...I have a mission for you." With a sweep of his cape, Il Palazzo reached his hand out, pointing to the massive woman in the pit.

From head to toe, the massive revolutionary wobbled with glee, the tremors knocking Hyatt down on her side. "Yes! Oh, my Lord, I've been waiting four long years and eleven months for this route with you to continue! The anticipation has made your loyal servant tense and achy!" She saluted, her fingers cutting through some of the elegant drapes, before reaching her thick forehead. With every movement, a thousand of her joints popped, and floods of dust erupted everywhere. "I'm ready for whatever trials may befall me! Through style inconsistencies, retcons, and abandoned plot hooks! "Regardless, we must put that energy to use." Il Palazzo sat on the piece of ceiling replacing his throne, his purple hair flowing in the wind. He made a mental note to fix those gaps in the ceiling and walls. "Your new assignment... Is to press the 'back' button on your browser twice. Then, select the other route. The violent path, if you will." The valiant leader flipped his laptop monitor upright once more, letting his yellow eyes focus on it. Interactives were currently unavailable. He reloaded the page.

She blinked in confusion for a moment, eyelashes loud enough that people outside the secret base could hear. "Huh? Choose the violent path? But Excel's under your power! How many times has a gigantic girl in a story surrendered her free will for a normal-sized guy's desires?"

Hyatt counted on her fingers, looking pensive. "How many giantess stories were written by normal-sized guys?"

Il Palazzo scratched his narrow chin. "Precisely. It just so happens that many people's desire is for a girl to step on or eath them." He swung his hand out dramatically, and pressed F5. "Let me make my request clear and succinct: return to the beginning. Leave this base, and do as you will on the other storyline. Try not to snap any modem cables on the way out."

Hyatt stood to her trembling legs, smiling. "I understand, Lord Il Palazzo. I don't have any preference about which option the reader selects."

Pumping her arms in excitement, the larger agent's emerald eyes glimmered, lighting up the base from corner to corner. "Oh, great Il Palazzo! You trust Excel so much, you'd let her follow the violent route! And without displaying any fear or hesitation!" She hugged him, smothering him in the massive orbs of her chest, flesh partly revealed from the tears. "They say 'If you love something, let it free' - and I feel so much like a something! But additionally, even more so, like a someone!"

As she shouted, her body rocketed and bumped with the energy of a pinball. It gave Il Palazzo the experience of being on a roller coaster - with a lower cost, fewer children, and louder screaming in his ears. Between bounding tit flesh and fabric, the fearless leader turned his head to the laptop screen. The webpage wasn't loading; he moved a compressed arm to refresh it again. "I'm glad you agree. But should you disrupt me again during the next few hours, I will not hesitate to attack you with the most powerful weapon available."

Excel stepped away; her boss fell on his feet, unglued from the mountains of meat. She smiled. "Understood! I'm certain that won't come back to bite me in the rear quarters!" Shedding a few tears, she braced her fists, and turned to Hyatt. "Well, it's sad to say goodbye so soon... Are you ready to take the alternate option?"

Hyatt calmly put her palms together. "I'm prepared. Now, if I remember, I was stuck on your sole in that first chapter. So to make sure everything's in order..." Upon reaching the end, splattered flat below on her stomach, she slithered underneath her senior's turquoise boot - and lodged herself underneath it.

131111.title: The Requisite Abrupt Ending Chapter

choices: Excel reaches city hall with no issues
Watanabe gets there first - they can prepare a counter-attack
13112.content:
Excel basked in self-awe from her last declaration. She stood like an unmoving statue, the very image of a revolutionary heroine. Well, except for the fact that she moved. A lot. Even in this sudden moment of stillness, her long-stretching hair caught the wind, her stomach moved in and out with each giant breath, and her green eyes scanned everything around. This was it. No more limitations of strength, money, or network censors. The towering ACROSS agent was free from the fetters of rationality and good taste.

She got to work right away. Her eyes narrowed as she trotted confidently towards a large building, pantomiming a grabbing movement, filled with the glee and energy of a child choosing a new toy. Suddenly, she punched a hole in it, the materials cleanly crumbling around her fist, falling to the streets below. The woman smiled, admiring her handiwork on this corrupt infrastructure.

Just a test, a sample of the changes she'd make in the name of Il Palazzo's will.

Most of the nondescript masses below gazed up in horror and awe. At first glance, the entire population seemed captivated with Excel's beauty. But upon further inspection, there were numerous straight women in the crowd, some gay men, and an odd few asexuals. And at another glance, most other people were too horrified to be aroused, and wouldn't even consider a giantess to be remotely attractive in the first place.

Weirdos.

In any case, an atmosphere of panic filled the air. Excel had already started fishing her hands through the buildings, humming to herself as the fingers tore windows apart.

"All the best rampages have the pretty lady grabbing some random nobody off the streets... Carrying him in inappro-pro places while he sits around oogling her and-slash-or quivering in fear..."

Putting a rubble-covered finger to her lips, she leaned over, tearing another chunk of building out and shaking its contents into her palm. To her dismay, nobody seemed to be offering themselves to her conquest.

"C'mon, I'm completely un-relatable! We need someone to get the reader involved! My unmentionables are absolutely secure! Crash-tested, I promise! I can even get seat belts or stuff if you don't believe me!"

Few had seen this girl before, or what she had in mind. Those who HAD seen Excel before had even more difficulty guessing what the giant woman was about to do next. Even at normal height, she was destructive and unpredictable. They shuddered thinking how that would manifest here.

Watanabe navigated through disturbingly aimless crowds, huffing. Every so often, he tilted his head back to the woman - but couldn't bear to look at her for long. It made his mind wander to painful places. Instead, he focused on running. If he reached City Hall in time, the Municipal Force could launch a counter-attack!... As long as Iwata didn't start drooling over the giantess. With silent prayers, he kept dashing.

"Miss Ayasugi... Please be alright." He turned his head up to her one last time, grunting. "Oh, you maniac..."

Hyatt coughed up a bit of blood, peacefully resting under the sole of her senior's boot. She was slammed on it again and again as Excel continued her hunt for a companion/victim. As the rampaging woman's patience fell, she kicked her way through a massive building, all of its contents spilling on the streets below. The long, peach leg flew into the air, dislodging Hyatt; the woman was airborne for a second. Leaning in, Excel let Hyatt fall onto her nose, between globe-like eyes, cheeks spread out on either side in a deranged smile.

"Oh, Hyatt! You may know me, sure, but you're good as any stranger! Wanna be a hostage?"

Hyatt shook for just a bit, maintaining her peaceful, detached gaze. "Thank you, senpai. I accept."

"Yesss! Excel will no longer be forced to speak to herself!"

With a quick fist-pump, the massive woman leaped into the air, casually crushing a few buildings under the weight of her body. Hyatt was jolted from her position, before landing safely onto Excel's orange hair. She peered down at the city below, enjoying the rapid movement and smoking wrecks of social infrastructure, along with the reduced oxygen from her height.

"My, this feels nice. How high are we?"

"It depends!" The massive woman grabbed a car in her hand, watching it fill her palm, flipping it around as she continued marching through buildings. Her voice quieted to a still-booming whisper: "I mean - 'tween you and me, some size authors have NO sense of scale. The 50 foot woman? She was probably closer to a one-fifty." She squeezed the car between her fingers, grinding it into dust.

"Ah, so you're as tall as the story needs you to be."

Excel nodded, nearly sending Hyatt flying off again. "On that note, let's just return to our feature presentation: city domination! Tiny person obliteration! Fuel for masturbation! Hyatt, in this situation, how would you go about conquering the population?"

She rested her head on her chin for a few moments. "I never was good at political sciences, but we usually use senseless terrorism, correct?"

Clapping her hands together, Excel made another leap, kicking a building down. "Bingo! And we shall take terror to new heights and new lows! We march over to any nearby authorities, demand they give us the city, and tame the masses once and for all! And the nearest authority looks like..." Her eyes focused on a building in the distance. "That place! City hall!"

Smiling wistfully, the passenger followed her line of sight. "A good plan, senior... But how do we run a city when we get it? I'm sure if we didn't repair buildings you compromised, work around the economic crisis, and balance the industrial, commercial and residential sectors, there'd be wide-scale revolts..."

The destructive footsteps paused for just one moment, as Excel scratched her head, fighting instincts to toss a dirty look at her hostage. "T-that's Lord Il Palazzo's job, not mine!"

Nodding, she continued her march, skipping playfully and watching people and cars fly into the air.

"Besides, who cares if they revolt? Let them eat cake! It'll fatten them up! They'll taste better! We're in a giantess story, and here, might makes right!"

She took one great leap with her right leg.

"Three lefts make a right!"

Excel stomped three times with her left foot, grinding it into the pavement.

"And there will be no one left but the righteous!"

A left step, then a right.

"That's natural selection! Social Darwinism! God is Dead in his Heaven, all's right with the world! So you mustn't run away, Shinji- we should seize that Carpe Diem by the tail, and he shall evolve into a Gyarados Diem! Righting lefts and triumphing over evil, and that means we aren't looking left or right, just dashing forward aimlessly!"

Shaken with each little movement, Hyatt clutched onto a strand of orange hair, gripping tightly as she smiled. "Left! ...Pardon. Right! Ah, correct."

As the two women carried on their conversation, absolute anarchy reigned below. People scurried out of the way, only to be met with a titanic turquoise boot, or pillar-like fingers coming from a glove. Those who stayed indoors weren't safe, either - Excel's lumbering often knocked small chunks out of houses, when her curiosity didn't lead to her outright smashing portions of the city she deemed offensive to Il Palazzo's righteous rule.

"Run! Haha! In our presence, you are but ANTS!"

She took another massive step, wiping some cars off the heel of her sole.

"Crawling into my picnic basket and stealing my well-earned food!"

Seeing a building in her way, Excel simply started dashing, letting her body tear through the structure. Bits of debris and office rooms slid down her chest and legs - the whole structure bore her shapely silhouette for just a moment before it crumbled under its own weight.

"Then just giving it all to a queen like the brainless workers you are!"

Hyatt kept struggling to stay alive, bits of blood leaking from her lips. The world below felt distant, her senior's wild screams the only reality.

"Ants can carry many times their relative weight and have really tough exoskeletons- which is more than can be said about you!"

Putting a finger to her mouth, Excel's heels swept the streets as she thought.

"Maybe it'd be more accurate to compare you to termites, gnawing at the foundations of our glorious society. Well, anyways, I'm depriving you of your humanity! Psychological warfare, yay!"

At this, she brought her hands down, grabbing as many bits of F City as she could - people, cars, Puchuus - and tossing them into the air like confetti.

"What kind of weirdo talks to ants or termites, anyways?"

They rained down over her body, some getting stuck on her uniform, or against the expanse of her skin.

"I mean, the whole point of calling smaller people 'insects' is to imply they're of little importance to me. If a chick found an insect nest in the park and spent an hour killing them all, they would mean SOMETHING to her - she couldn't just use that 'they were in my way' excuse. If I keep on using a sufficient amount of my energy on you and holding a conversation with you people, that means I probably do care about you, at least a smidgen-or-so. And considering the whole point of this one-sided discussion was to express how insignificant and unnoticeable you are compared to me, Excel can't help but get this strange feeling that she's stomped into a circle-type-shape and self-defeated herself."

Looking a bit dejected at her inability to psychologically dominate the city, she contented herself with physically dominating it, headed for City Hall to enforce her lord's will.

"Hyatt, please let this be a lesson if you ever get huge: deeds, not words!"

"Understood, senior."
13112.title: The part we've all been waiting for: Violence!

choices: Go with Shiouji's plan: ACROSS Giantess vs. Municipal Giantess!
Go with Nabeshin's plan: Excel vs. Self-Insert!
131122.content:
One rapid step from the Goliath-sized boot sent Watanabe nearly flying in the air. In the reflections of the trembling skyscrapers, he could see brief glimpses of Excel's short-clad legs, the bounce in her bosom as it inadvertently crashed into another structure, and, as she leaned over the people, a toothy, wild-eyed smile. Most disturbingly, she was getting closer; though he dared not look behind him, the details in the reflections kept getting clearer. Though he dared not peek back, her fleeing neighbor could nearly make out the exact buildings she'd destroyed simply by the rubble...

Trying to move his head away, he spotted two familiar faces at a low-budget ramen stand. Iwata, with spiked hair, sat next to the rather pudgy Sumiyoshi; both fellow Municipal workers. Both fully focused on the meal on the table before them.

As Watanabe approached, Iwata could feel the man's angered breath ruffling his shirt from behind. Without even glancing to his friend, he swallowed some noodles and said: "Look, I know what you're gonna say. But the lines here are shorter than they've ever been! Panic and anarchy really makes getting food easier." Ever-silent, Sumiyoshi nodded in agreement.

To prove this statement, fingers the size of tree trunks suddenly fell around the stand, scooping it up from the ground. The chef fell out of it, a loud thud on his elongated head. The table lifted away, along with the two bowls. The neighbors remained still, necks craning up in terror to see Excel's tongue wrap around the shop - and quickly engulf the entire thing in her mouth, chomping it into nothing with a few solid bites.

From atop her scalp, Hyatt waved down: "Why, hello, Mr. Watanabe."

He gasped, reaching his arms as high as he could, leaping up into the sky. "MS. AYASUGI! H-hang in there! We're going to save you!"

At this, Excel's enormous eyes suddenly darted downwards. Her neighbor could see him and his coworkers reflecting in them. "Strangers! A singing voice in my head says I should trample and kick you down!"

Her turquoise sole lifted from the ground, hanging above the three paralyzed companions... Before the revolutionary's head twisted to a building in the distance. The F City Tower; specifically, her reflection in it. She waved to it inquisitively, watching the mirrored image mimic her action. Placing her boot down absurdly close to the trio, she snapped her fingers. "Aha! It's my insidious doppelganger, Excel Kobayashi! I have no idea what you're doing this big, but you won't escape!"

This distraction was JUST what they needed. Watching everything shake as Excel dashed away, Watanabe wordlessly grabbed his friends, continuing his journey.

Excel's neighbor kicked open the door to City Hall, tugging both of his neighbors in with him. He darted to a familiar room, marked by the word "POLITICS" in capital letters. The planning table for The Department of City Security sat in the center; this was where the pen-pushers could figure out how to best respond to a major threat. Two figures had already taken their seats. At one end, Dr. Kabapu. Nobody really knew where he got his doctorate, or what exact authority he had; but his fake mustache and glasses simply demanded attention. At the other side sat a woman.

Name: Misaki Matsuya
Age: 20-something
Hair: red
Gender: Female
Wearing: White dress shirt with yellow vest and skirt
Height: Her trading figurine is approx. 5.5 inches
Personality: the type who gets angry when people try to summarize her personality in one line
Voice Actress: Yuka Imai/Tiffany Grant/Barbara De Bortoli
Favorite interaction: Iwata once told me she likes handplay but I don't trust him

Matsuya angrily shooed away her character profile. She hated it when those things followed her around. The municipal worker gave a long look over the room and asked: "Have we reached the breaking point?"

The man answered: "Yes. I feared we'd reach this position..."

Still catching his breath from the long dash, holding a hand to the wall, Watanabe blurted out: "What? What's with the ominous mumbling?"

At the head of the table, Kabapu explained with the most stern, grim gaze possible: "We've officially hit the DEEP LORE. The point in the story where the author assumes readers are looking for something other than quick laughs, and freezes all giantess interaction so that talking heads can give exposition."

Sumiyoshi's lips didn't budge, but the look in his glasses told everyone his thoughts: Lasted longer than giantessfancomics usually do, at least.

The Department of City Security sat together - an aura of fear and despair floating over their heads, the smell of Kabapu floating in their noses. Occasional tremors and battle cries outside did nothing to calm their nerves.

The good doctor was the one to break the silence: "Briefly state your ideas on how to neutralize this threat. Too much time, and we get stomped out. Or bored to death."

"I don't understand why we're having this conversation." Matsuya shook her head bitterly. "I say we just nuke her."

The mustached man said: "Size change interactives run under the assumption that nuclear weapons are unpredictable magical black boxes. At best, they'll do nothing. At worst, we risk giving her goddess powers."

Iwata leaned back in his chair and shrugged. "Meh, that wouldn't be so bad. If she has Benten's powers, she'll be a great artist. If she gets Athena's powers, we'll get a cool Saint Seiya sequel. I can live with that. Now, if we go into the Norse goddesses- that's where things get tricky..."

Sumiyoshi's silence spoke clear words.

Slamming both hands on the table, Watanabe asked: "Why don't we just send the JSDF in, and shoot her to the ground? Then maybe, Miss Ayasugi..." He held back a few tears.

Kabapu answered: "The military cannot spare much of their budget to F City. Besides, her flesh is either too thick to pierce - like her skull - or at her size, skin cells rebuild faster. There's always some sort of pseudo-scientific explanation."

"Like AT fields! Or a wall of psychic energy!" Iwata squealed. "Sweet, we need a special plot device to kill her!"

A few footsteps echoed from a shady corner. A mauve-haired man in a doctor's suit came in: the team's roboticist, Dr. Shiouji. He played with his glasses before enunciating: "May I join in? I've thoroughly studied the multitudes of commissioned art and fiction involving giant Chibiusa."

Matsuya pontificated: "Go neuter yourself, doctor."

Shiouji ejaculated: "Ah, you make me laugh." He ejaculated again before continuing: "Think in terms of the narrative. When given the choice, what type of self-respecting interactive reader picks 'giantess shrinks and everybody is happy and the story ends', when the option above reads, 'giantess keeps on rampaging'?"

"So we're doomed." Watanabe let out a groan, grasping at his hair.

"Doomed," Shiouji said, "unless the option where we win seems appealing to the readers."

"But what would appeal to- aaaah, I see where this is going!" Iwata's eyes gained a sudden blaring fire to them. "Fight giantess with giantess! A sexy catfight between the rampaging woman and some girl on our end - and a quick victory for the Municipal Force!"

"But where do we find a giantess?" Matsuya glanced around, worried.

Shiouji gave the smile of a priest at a funeral. "Well, we come up with some convoluted way to grow you. Or Ms. Momochi. Or, I build an immense Ropponmatsu unit. Then, as Iwata said, we engage with this foe in combat..."

The woman shook her head, getting up to leave the table. "I refuse. What will the public think of their municipality? We'll be seen as monsters, or worse: sex objects! I will not surrender my dignity for the sake of a fantasy."

Kabapu stood up more triumphantly, hands on her hips. "You either surrender your dignity, or the city. It's a choice I made long ago- and I, for one, am glad I chose F City, F Prefacture!"

As usual, Sumiyoshi stared blankly forward. YOU had dignity once?

"There's always a second option..."

From an even shadier, more-poorly-lit corner, emerged a wonderfully handsome man with an astounding afro, a smoking cigarette, a completely original jacket-and-tie combo, and a suave demeanor.

"Nabeshin? When I came into City Hall, I didn't see a sign reading 'open house emergency response meeting'!" Watanabe glared towards him.

"Heh. Heh heh heh." He snickered with the same ambiguous laugh of a man about to teleport behind someone with a katana. "Don't be so quick to show me the door. You're talking to the author's super-powered self-insert character."

By now, all eyes pointed to him. Kabapu stepped closer, inquisitively. "How can we trust you and your afro, Nabeshin? You're a loose cannon!"

Nabeshin just nodded his head slowly, with his arms crossed. "True, but - like many of my kin - I HATE seeing uppity ladies challenging my control of the narrative. I'll take care of her with my bare fists. And my charm. And my scathing, tongue-in-cheek, elbow-in-rib, dick-in-hand meta-humor."

With a smile, Iwata said: "If there's one thing you can rely on more than a writer's lust, it's their ego."

Matsuya paused for a second, before her head tilted. "But... If you're the author, aren't YOU the one who made her grow in the first place?"

His lower lip bulged out in a pout back to her. "Look, do you want me to save your rear windows, or not?"

Kabapu said: "I wish we had more than two choices here... But the cost is too high!"

The cost of what?, Sumiyoshi silently asked.

"Writing.com Paid Membership!"
131122.title: Counter-attack on a Titan

1311222.content:
Kabapu adjusted his glasses, eying Shiouji. "How do you intend to grow a woman who can fight this beast?"

Shiouji adjusted his own glasses back, sliding them down the end of his nose. "I'll make an endless series of 'what girl to grow?' choice chapters, fill none of them in, and hope a wandering author comes to save us. If nobody arrives within a year, I will add chapters branching from these choices reading 'what height should she be'? And if nobody answers that distress call, I'll make more chapters, this time reading 'how should she grow'?"

The mustached man's glasses fell right off his face. "That's too dangerous. Nabeshin, it looks like our hopes are on your dandruff-covered shoulders."

The author's self-insert shrugged, bearing a grin worthy of a Dreamworks poster. "Suits me. If the reader chose the other option, I'd find some way to sneak myself in, anyway." Tearing a rocket launcher from his fluffy afro, he charged out the window, shattering the glass as he jumped into the city below in an action-ready pose.

With a nod, the team's roboticist stepped away. "It suits me, too. A project of this scale would've interrupted my conveniently timed vacation to Thailand." He swept all the contents of his desk into a suitcase, and snapped his fingers; a pair of robots broke through the wall and pulled him away before anyone could
question him.

"But I'm not happy!" Iwata groaned, holding his hands over his spiked hair. "Urgh, I was all worked up for a real catfight! Is ANYTHING sexy going to happen here?"

Misaki's hand collided with that hair sharply. "Nobody cares what you want! Our job is NOT putting on shows for creepy fetishists."

Sumiyoshi kept still, but silently emoted: Nobody cares what any of us secondary characters want, really. We'll be lucky if we even show up after this chapter.

Finally, Watanabe stared through the undestroyed part of the window, gazing dramatically over the trembling F City. His fingertips touched the glass softly, as he looked over his reflection and the skyscrapers still standing. "Then let me use this last moment to say... Nabeshin, you'd better not screw this up."

Outside, the F City tower was missing from the skyline. In its place rested a mountain of floorboards, office supplies, shattered glass, people who weren't very fast, and, mostly, Excel. A very frazzled, red-skinned Excel, panting, removing tiny bits of glass from her body, and struggling to pull back up her now-moistened shorts. Her thighs rested on what was left of surrounding landmarks.

"I... Hah..." Her words came out as a low murmur, rumbling the ruined neighborhood. "...I really don't know what happened there. First, I see my evil twin, and challenge her to a fight. We get into this intense duel, and she's holding up to all my blows. Punching back pretty good, too! Then, I can't help but notice how... How charming and attractive my double looks! After that, after that - shame clouds Excel's mind."

Hyatt, quietly wiping her face clean of blood, lifted a finger from her place in her partner's enormous ponytail. "Senior, from where I'm standing, it seems that you tried to have sex with reflective glass at that point."

"Thank you for reminding me!" Excel groaned, pausing to fiddle with the buttons on her torn leg-wear.

"And in the process, destroyed the building that this glass was coating." She smiled brightly.

"Good recap." The gargantuan woman winced as she tugged another bit of pokey glass from her breast.

"I'm impressed! A building that has previously withstood magnitude 6 earthquakes and 50 m/s winds couldn't stand to bi-curious urges. Or were they auto-sexual urges? Objectum-sexual urges?"

"THANK. YOU. HYATT." These earth-shaking words came from behind her shut fangs, forced into a pained grimace as her fingers tightened into fists below. "This cunning trick can't fool ACROSS again! Once this city rests under Lord Il Palazzo's guiding thumb, Excel's poking finger will suggest that he makes all windows one-way."

Dusting off a few remaining chunks of rubble again, she stretched her massive neck, trying to remember what her destination was - and inadvertently tossing the hair-bound passenger back and forth. City Hall came back into her line of vision; it took her about five seconds to process this information, focus on it, and regain her stride. Not nearly enough time for people in the neighboring city block to run away from the soles of her turquoise boots.

With her confidence and shamelessness back in full swing, she called out gleefully: "We now return to the Attack of the Arbitrary-Number-Foot-Tall Excel!" Arms stretched like an airplane, she cut through previously untouched areas, leaving only dust trails behind her. The fingers cut buildings like knives through butter, leaving the inhabitants with nice sunroofs and relief that noisy upstairs neighbors would no longer be a problem. In her absent-minded jog, she barely bothered to keep her eyes on the road. "Growing again? I'm a little exhausted now..." Hyatt laughed, as she felt the familiar tingling over her body. "And I think this size is excessive already."

"That's no way to talk!" Excel shouted to her. She laughed, hands on her still-expanding hips, breaking into song: "Banana peels, pratfalls, and every mistake..."

They expanded more, quickly outgrowing the crowd of girls around them. Glistening masses of galaxies sparkled like gemstones around, squeezed by the growing bodies. "One ideal through it all, everything is for his sake!"

Hyatt felt her heel colliding with one tiny universe - the one where Excel chose to thank Il Palazzo instead of conquering the city. That branch would never find its conclusion. She spotted dozens of other tiny universes that contained this interactive's worlds - Asagi's Big Debut. Stella, My Universal Girlfriend. And there were thousands of these dimensions out there, hundreds of writing dot com stories, all laid out for them.

"So if nothing else, I guess that would be..." Excel grinned, diving in and rolling around in them like a girl in a ball pit. "...A really weird kind of love... called loyalty!"

So, if you log in to writing dot com and find a perfectly-good giantess story gone, don't blame the site owners - its universe may have been lost in the valleys of Hyatt's flesh. If a furry size interactive you liked is missing, don't blame the staff for deleting it - Excel may have considered it emergency rations, and added it to those in her stomach. And don't be too mad when you can't view items due to heavy server loads - any website trying to bear ACROSS' explosive expansion would have trouble keeping them contained. Just hope that they don't break out into our dimension some day...

An infinitesimally small whimper sounded out. Excel felt something beyond microscopic crawling over her skin, scurrying around.


"MENCHI!" Her scream was loud enough to reduce a galaxy to dust. She groped over her body, trying futilely to grab him. "You still haven't put in your part for our conquest! Come on, come heeere, girl!"

14122.content:
"Um, Stella?"

The embodiment of the entire universe looked up from her desk, Mike looking at her with a slight smile upon his face. She grinned back widely, but toned it down a bit.

Don't want to come on too strong... or I might scare him off. She thought.

In reality, the backpack had nothing in it, but with but a whim she could reach in and conjure up anything required for the mundane tasks that school required.

"You uh... mind eating lunching with me?"

Let's start with something small, Stella thought. Something big might well scare him.

Stella took another bite of her sandwich and chewed pensively.

"Well?" asked Mike.

Stella swallowed. "See, here, watch." With a thought Stella's sandwich was whole again, and was filled with peanut butter and jelly.

Mike jumped up in alarm. "What was that?"

"I told you. I can control everything. I wanted the sandwich to be whole again, so it was."

Mike stood silent for a moment, looking from the sandwich, to Stella, and back and forth. Then he fled.

"Mike, wait!" Stella called after him, but he simply looked over his shoulder and ran faster.

Running herself, she made her sandwich vanish and shifted her bag onto her shoulders from ten feet away. She caught up with him just as he, not looking where he was going in his panicked dash, was about to run right into a wall.

With a thought from the universe he ran through it, and Stella followed.

The two found themselves in the entrance hall of the school building, except that they were dangling above the basement, the floor intersecting them roughly around their belly buttons. A few students noticed them, but Stella simply made them think nothing of the sight.

Stella thought again and the two swiftly lifted up until they stood on the floor.

"What was that?"

"Well, I couldn't let you run into a wall!"

"Look, Stella, this, this is just too much. Just... just, I need some space."

"Mike!"

"Just stay away!"

Stella was rooted to the spot as Mike ran again, this time not getting ten steps before running into the school's biggest bully.

Mike's bag stayed on his shoulders, but the other boy's books went flying. Mike picked himself up and began to gather them, apologizing as he did.

The bully lifted him bodily, motioning for his gang to get his books.

"Watch where you're going, you little twerp. I think you need a lesson in respect for your betters."

Stella was frozen into inaction as the love of her life got his nose broken, his jaw dislocated, the wind knocked out of him with a swift kick to the gut and ended up screaming silently in pain on the floor after a hard knee to his groin. She couldn't decide whether to help Mike, and risk scaring him off for good, or not help, and risk him hating her for not helping.

As Mike picked himself up and dragged himself to the nurse's office, his tormentor looking on smugly, Stella looked after him longingly.

"What do you want a little shit like him for?" the bully said, ogling Stella. "You need a real man." His gang laughed obediently.

"If that's what a real man does," replied the universe, indicating the trail of blood on the ground, "I think I'll stick to unreal ones." Then she walked off in another direction.

Stella wandered her way into the school's cafeteria, gravitating toward an oddly-dressed girl sitting alone in a corner.

"Do you mind if I join you?" she asked.

The girl looked up briefly. "No, not at all. Please."

Stella sat down and, as she pulled out her sandwich, she changed it into a garden salad. Opening it, she took the little container of vinaigrette she had made with it, poured it over the vegetables and began to eat, finding the experience different, but still pleasing.

Her companion looked up again. "Hey, aren't you that new girl? S... something?"

"Stella. Stella Cassiopeia."

"Right. I'm Cecilia Margaret Voclain. Pleased to meet you, Stella."

"And I you, Cecilia."

"Cecilia Margaret. Cecilia's my aunt, and Margaret's my other aunt."

Stella nodded. "I'll remember that."

"You're new here, so a bit of advice. If you value your social life, find another friend. I'm not exactly Miss Popularity around here."

Stella looked around. "They don't seem as interesting as you."

Cecilia Margaret sipped a bit of soup before replying. "So what brings you in here? I saw you heading out to the bleachers with Mike."

"Oh, this and that," Stella said, hiding her pain. "It... didn't go well."

"Oh? Tell me about it."

Stella probed her companion in silence, then decided she could trust the strange girl. "We had a bit of an argument, then he ran into someone and got beat up for it."

"Big, tough guy, gang of big tough guys with him?"

"Yeah."

"Real piece of work, Lauren. Always been ticked off about having a 'girl's name'. What did you do?"

"Do? Nothing, I just stood there."

"You didn't even try to intervene? You're a better person than I am, I probably would have at least tried to get him on the floor. Brown belt in jiu-jitsu, but don't tell anyone."

"I won't."

Cecilia Margaret looked at Stella closely. "But what really happened? He didn't run off for no reason."

Stella made a decision. "I'll tell you, but you've got to promise not to tell anyone."

"I promise," and Stella could tell her new friend was sincere.

"He was scared of me, well, of what I can do."

"Oh? What can you do?"

"Anything I want."

"How do you mean, anything you want? Anyone can do anything they want, they just have to face the consequences."

"No, I mean I can do anything. If I want to do it, I can do it." Stella indicated her half-eaten salad, then changed it into a bowl of cottage cheese.

Cecilia Margaret blinked, and Stella waited, hoping she hadn't made another mistake.

"Cool! What else can you do?"

Stella ignored the question. "Anyway, I showed him some of what I could do, and saved him from running into a wall, and, well, I think I might've scared him off for good."

"What did he say, exactly?"

Stella repeated Mike's words verbatim.

"Give him a little time and a little space."

"But I want him," Stella said, very softly. "He's so special, and he doesn't even know it. I love him."

"That's just it," her friend replied, just as quietly. "He doesn't know. He doesn't get how special he is that someone like you would love him."

Stella smiled faintly. "That's not the only thing that makes him special."

Cecilia Margaret changed topics. "So, tell me, you live around here?"

"No... no. I live rather far away."

"How about you come to my place after school? I'll help you figure out Mike if you show me some more of your cool powers."

Stella looked up into her new friend's eyes, and saw someone she could trust. "All right."

"Good! Meet you out front after school then?"

"Sure."

Just then the bell rang, warning the students to get to their next class. Stella and Cecilia Margaret went their separate ways, the human's eyes going wide as Stella made her bowl of cottage cheese vanish.

As she walked to her next class, Stella rearranged the seating plans for her classes, putting herself as far from Mike as possible. She had to force herself to appear to pay attention to the lessons.

At the final bell, Stella rushed straight to the front door, and waited for about a minute until Cecilia Margaret showed up. The two rode the bus in silence until it stopped at the side of the road and the human led the universe off.

The two waited until the bus was reasonably far away, then Cecilia Margaret walked straight into the brush. Stella followed.

"Where are we going?"

"To my place. It's a bit secluded, but I prefer it that way."

After a minute of trudging through tall grass, the two emerged onto a packed trail, with nobody in sight.

"You said you wanted to see some of my powers?"

"Oh, that's fine. I like this walk."

"Well, if you insist..."

"Nah. I like the walk, but hey, I promised to help you with Mike."

"And I promised you show you some of my powers. Just envision your house."

Stella picked up the clear image from her friend's mind and in an instant they were standing at the front door.

"Cool! Just who are you, anyway?"

"I'm the universe. Reality is me."

Cecilia Margaret unlocked the door and went in. Stella followed to find herself in a large, ornate foyer.

"My folks are rich," the human explained, "and they gave me this place on my eighteenth birthday. I could have had a number of different places, but I chose this one for the solitude. It's a bit of a hike to get the bus, but it's worth it."

"So if they're so rich, why aren't you popular?"

"Well... I'm a bit weird, not really cut out to be one of the cool kids. I don't like what they like, don't think like they think."

"What do you like?"

"I'm a nerd," said Cecilia Margaret, leading Stella into a room with one wall dominated by a huge flatscreen television, and the others with floor-to-ceiling shelves of DVDs.

Stella scanned them with her mind, familiarizing herself with her friend's interests.

"That, and I've got, well, eclectic beliefs, or, rather, not really any. Not something you really want to admit around here."

"Is there anything you do believe?"

"Not as such. I look at various religions and spiritual traditions, try to find what's good in them. There's pearls in all of them. 'Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.' 'An it harm none, do what ye will.' That sort of thing."

Stella nodded and subtly altered her friend's collection. "And I don't shake any of that for you?"

"Not unless you're going to tell me I have to worship you or something," Cecilia Margaret chuckled.

1412221.content:
"No, no," replied Stella. "You don't need to worship anyone or anything you don't want to."

Cecilia Margaret left the room heading toward her kitchen, and Stella followed.

"So what's it like being the universe?"

"It's hard to describe. I'm everywhere at once--I'm everything at once, really--and it's so easy just to reach out and change something. I could micromanage everything if I wanted to. But I don't. Mostly I just watch things unfold."

The human began pulling things out of her fridge and turned on her oven. "And what about having a human body for your own consciousness?"

"Really, not much different. I knew exactly what it was like to have a human body before, of course, but I never took control of one. It's interesting to choose the sensations I experience, but most of them I've experienced anyway, through others."

"Except that there aren't really others, I suppose."

"Since I mostly observe instead of interfering, from my point of view there might as well be."

Suddenly Stella seemed to notice what her friend was doing. With a thought the food was prepared and on the table in the next room.

Cecilia Margaret blinked. "Please don't. I enjoy cooking--preparing my own meal makes eating it all the more satisfying to me."

"I am sorry." Stella restored matters to the way they had been.

"Thank you," replied the human, who resumed her preparations.

"So what else can you do?" asked Cecilia Margaret after a silence.

"Anything I want. Reality is what I want it to be, so if I decide that something should happen, it will. If I decide it shouldn't happen, it won't."

Walking quickly back and forth between two tasks, the human said, "So if you decided that I should be in two places at once, I would be?"

"You would, yes," said the universe as she granted the human's request.

"Way cool!" said Cecilia Margaret in stereo. The one on Stella's left continued to talk, her other body occupied with both arms in use and holding a wooden spoon in her mouth, at least until Stella noticed that and granted the mortal four arms, and she continued working as if she had always had them, not noticing the change.

"Can you do stuff like alter history, time travel, that stuff?"

"What you perceive as time is just another thing I can control. I could alter history, if I wanted to. I could fix part of the future, too. But those are the past and the future as you perceive them. I generally choose to perceive them that way also, but I do not have to."

"So you can control everything, change anything, but usually don't?"

"Pretty much. I want nothing but the best for everything in me, but I know that they have to be allowed to make mistakes. It always pains me when those mistakes prove disastrous."

"I can imagine. I don't know anything about the rest of the universe, but I know that even here we have experienced horrendous atrocities."

"And each of them hurt me, as did each of those that occurred on other worlds."

"So there is life out there?"

"Well, there's life out there if I say there's life out there," the universe said lightly.

"But absent your intervention?"

"That's a discovery that I let species make for themselves."

Cecilia Margaret finished her work and put a dish in her oven. Setting a timer, both her bodies turned to face Stella.

"So there is."

"Yes, but as I said, I let species discover that on their own. I've told you, but you'll have to keep that knowledge to yourself."

"Oh? And what are you going to do to stop me?" the human asked with a grin.

"I've already done it. You can discuss these matters with me, but not with anyone else. I am sorry for interfering with your mind, but it is better than interfering with all of humanity, so I can't let you communicate that knowledge."

"Hey, even if it doesn't happen in my lifetime--and I don't think it will--at least I'll know." Suddenly she noticed her extra limbs. "Whoa, awesome! It's like I've always had these--I didn't even notice them until now."

"You see? I didn't want you to notice them until now, so you didn't."

Cecilia Margaret waved her eight arms around for a short time, until her face fell when Stella restored her to her original condition.

"Perhaps another time," said Stella.

"I suppose a taste is better than never experiencing it. I will treasure the memory."

The human set about setting the table, hesitating on putting down a second place. "Will you be joining me?"

"I do not require sustenance, and as such I could not take what is yours."

"That's fine. I made something for two."

"I see." Stella thought, and the additional ingredients used appeared back in her friend's fridge and cupboards.

The timer went off, and Cecilia Margaret took her concoction out of her oven. Half the pan was normal, but the other half had a moving pattern of galaxies on it.

"I take it that half is yours, then?"

"Yes. I created it myself and have given you back the ingredients you used in making that part."

"You didn't have to."

"I could not take from you that which you might need in future."

The human shrugged, took the tray into her dining room, divided the meal between the two plates--the pan went back to normal as she did--put the rest of her cooking implements in her dishwasher and motioned for Stella to join her at the table.

"So, food made by the universe. May I try some?"

Stella silently, but noticeably, switched small portions on their plates. She popped her piece of the human's meal in her mouth.

"Not bad," she said. "To be honest I had thought that food prepared by others would not compare to what I create, but you are talented."

Cecilia Margaret ate her piece with a bit of trepidation. Then her eyes rolled up, and she leaned back and moaned in pure pleasure.

When she recovered, she said, "I do not compare to you. That was, without a doubt, the best food I have ever tasted. I think some people would quite literally kill for even a small sliver of anything you make." She took another bite of her own creation. "And I am glad you enjoyed what I made."

"I am glad you found what I made pleasurable. But I cannot give you more--it is plain that doing so at this time would cause brain damage, and while I could repair it, I would be unable to let you remember anything but that first piece."

Cecilia Margaret cocked an ear back. "So your powers are not limitless?"

Stella shrugged.

Just then a loud buzzing was heard from the human's back pocket. Pulling out an advanced phone, she took one look at it, said, "Sorry, I have to deal with this," and busied herself for a few minutes tapping away madly.

Stella knew what her friend had been doing, but nonetheless asked, "What was that?"

"Don't you know?" the human said with a grin, then continued. "I take a look at my investment portfolio at least once a day. Normally I've finished dinner by now, but it's not every day I'm entertaining the universe." She took another bite.

"I am sorry I have disrupted your usual activities."

"Don't be. I invited you, remember?"

Only a short time passed until the two finished their meal, and then Cecilia Margaret cleared the table, put it all in the dishwasher--she noticed Stella's plate, cutlery and glass were perfectly clean, but out of habit put them in anyway--put in detergent--"My folks have one that'll take regular dish soap, but they weren't willing to spend quite that much on this place"--started the machine and headed for the stairs to her basement.

Stella followed and emerged into an open space, support columns dotting the area. Cecilia Margaret was looking in a cabinet filled with musical instruments. A few seconds passed before she took out a clarinet and some sheet music, then walked over to the area's lone chair and stand and began to warm up.

Stella looked on and, after a minute of listening to the music, thought.

Cecilia Margaret stopped shortly after. "Please don't. I play because I wish to improve. If you give me the ability, I do not feel as if I have earned it."

"But you have earned my friendship, and with it what I may do for you."

"And for that I shall always be thankful. But to me, part of being human is the struggle to better myself."

"It seems I have more to learn than I had thought." But as she restored her friend to her former ability, she thought again.

For the second time that evening, Cecilia Margaret experienced perfection as Stella's music enfolded her, supporting and enhancing her own, giving her an infinitesimal glimpse into the nature of her friend's true existence.
