choices: The alarm goes off with just enough time to catch the bus.
Cecilia Margaret always wakes up early.
14122211.content:
After Cecilia Margaret recovered from the experience, she put her clarinet away and unsteadily walked upstairs to the second floor of her house. She opened one of the doors down the hallway from the stairs.

"This is one of my guest rooms," she said. "You're welcome to it, if you want. Or," she said, grinning and with a twinkle in her eye, "my bed is always warm..."

"No, thank you," Stella said, easily discerning her friend's meaning.

"All right. Well, there's a bathroom just through that door there"--she indicated a door inside the room--"fully stocked and all. Which reminds me: does the universe ever need to go?"

"I do not know. I suppose this human body may, if I let it digest my food."

"Hm, maybe you'd better not, then. I've got top-notch purification systems here, but I don't know if they could handle whatever parts of your food might seep out. I might just get that brain damage."

"Perhaps you are right," and Stella removed all traces of her lunch and dinner from her body.

"Right. Well, if you feel like it, the master bedroom is two doors that way on the right. Just come on in."

"Thank you."

Cecilia Margaret walked off and Stella entered the guest room, closing the door.

It opened again. "Oh! Almost forgot. If you want to use the computers, go ahead. They're really advanced--you can't get that stuff in regular stores. They run just about everything. Just choose a username and password and it'll set up an account for you on my central server. If you want any games, other programs, whatever, just order them and don't worry about the cost. It'll fill in the details automatically. My folks never take too close a look at the bills." She grinned broadly.

"I could not impose in that way."

"I insist. I would do no less for any other guest."

Stella smiled. "Thank you."

Cecilia Margaret nodded and walked back to her bedroom, and Stella closed the door again.

Walking into the bathroom, she quickly took in everything there. She supposed any human would find it luxurious, but she simply envisioned herself clean, then shifted her clothes into comfortable pyjamas.

Turning on one of the computers, after a few seconds it prompted her. She chose "universe" as a username, smiling as she did, and for a password entered a random 107-character string which she easily committed to memory.

Taking a closer look at it, she noticed its components were decaying very slowly as she used it, so she repaired the damage done to date and put the parts in a state of stasis, allowing them to function but preventing the negative effects.

She found nothing of any immediate interest, and her thoughts wandered to Mike.

She took the computer back to the login prompt and walked outside, making her clothes vanish as she went, feeling the night breeze on her bare skin.

Looking up, she banished the clouds, revealing a starry night.

The stars began to move, changing colour and brightness. As Stella commanded, they formed into a perfect image of Mike, looking as he had that morning. The model rotated, showing Stella her love from all sides. As it came back around, it smiled and waved. Stella waved back, then reached back in time and restored the stars and clouds to their original positions, leaving the vision as a memory for her and her alone.

She leaned against the wall of the house, so lost in thoughts of Mike that she didn't notice the intruders until a spotlight was shining on her.

Quickly she came to her senses. She could hear talking and, through the darkness, see dark-clothed men with weapons surrounding the house.

"Nab her," she heard. "We can have some fun with her later."

"And then the other one?"

"Affirmative."

Stella, still naked, walked over to stand in front of the main entrance. Three men crept out of the darkness, muzzles pointed at her.

"I'm sorry," she said, "but I cannot let you do this."

"You?" said one of them incredulously.

"I warn you--leave."

She heard the voice in the speaker's ear. "Forget about the fun. Kill her."

"Yes, sir."

Immediately three fully automatic weapons opened fire on Stella.

She felt the bullets hit her body, felt the blood pouring from her wounds, knew she should be blind from the shots to her eyes, mute from the ones through her throat, damaged from the ones through her brain, one of them taking half her scalp with it, and dead from the ones through her heart. She knew her lower jaw was half exposed.

The armed men advanced, still wary, expecting her to crumple any second.

"I did warn you. I am sorry."

The men charged.

A second later, they vanished.

Stella turned around and walked through the door of her friend's house, just in time to see Cecilia Margaret rush down the stairs, equally naked.

Stella hadn't looked at her friend's body, but suddenly realised just how attractive others might find it if she showed it off. Quickly sifting through her memories as an omniscient universe to determine her friend's usual attire, she determined that she hid her shape through a minimizer bra and baggy clothing, which were clearly quite effective at hiding her hourglass figure, large ass and huge breasts, and she supposed nobody knew that Cecilia Margaret went Brazilian. Her makeup, Stella realized, was designed to make her appear less attractive, as her natural beauty was stunning. Sensing a physical reaction from her human body, Stella deadened her sexual responses.

"What happened? And what happened to you?" she shrieked.

Stella looked down at herself, having forgotten to repair herself. With a thought she was as good as new. She held out a hand. "Let me show you."

Hesitantly, Cecilia Margaret came down the rest of the stairs and took it.

Immediately, the two found themselves looking down on Stella, outside the house, as she looked up and rearranged the night sky.

"You really do love him, don't you?"

"Yes. I do. I hope he will love me."

"You could make him love you. He'd never know the difference."

"I would know."

The scene progressed. "You're the only human who will know that any of this happened."

Cecilia Margaret watched as the men appeared, as they planned to kidnap the two of them and rape, then kill, Stella, as they emptied their ammunition belts into Stella's body, and as Stella banished them with a thought and walked back inside.

"You didn't kill them, or erase them from existence, did you?"

"No. I did the same as I had with the stars--send them back where they came from, make it so that never happened--except for the physical evidence on me, anyway."

"Could you give me a look inside their minds? I think I may know why they were here--above just kidnapping me--but I'd like to be sure."

Stella rewound the scene and put her friend in the mind of everyone present.

"I am sorry I cannot let you know more than my surface thoughts, but, and I mean no offense by this, to understand the thoughts of a universe, you must be a universe, and that is yet another thing beyond my power."

"I take no offense at simple facts," Cecilia Margaret said, shrugging. "Rather I am touched by the fact that, apart from Mike, my safety was foremost in your mind."

After witnessing the scene again, the human found herself in her foyer again, releasing the other's hand.

"Fuck!" she exclaimed. "I knew my dad had a lot of enemies, but fuck it, I never thought they'd find me here. Dammit, that's why I took this place..."

"One of them managed to slip a tracking device in your backpack," Stella explained. "I had hoped it would come to nothing, but that was clearly a vain hope."

"Damn, now I'll have to move. And only six months after getting here, dammit."

"No, you won't. I've altered the nature of this house. The only people who can even find it now are you, me, and anyone either of us allows to find it--as I cannot limit my own power, I must ask that you trust that I will not bring anyone who might wish you harm to this place--as well as anyone for whom it is necessary that they find it, so don't go abusing this gift to do anything illegal. Law enforcement officers will find it and you if I don't stop you first. But for anyone else, it will be as if it does not even exist."

Cecilia Margaret hugged her friend, whispering thanks in her ear. Letting go, she said, "Thank you. I realise we are safe now, but the memories you gave me... I do not think I will sleep soundly tonight. Please. I beg you."

Stella took her friend by the shoulders. "Since I am responsible for your unease, I will comfort you this night."

Hand in hand the two naked girls walked to Cecilia Margaret's bedroom, the human violently shaking her head when Stella gave them clothes, practically tearing hers off and attempting to do the same to Stella, who let her.

They sank into the bed, holding each other. Stella noted the time, and the time at which the alarm would sound. Slowing the universe, she held her friend, comforting her, allowing her the time to recover from what she had witnessed and come close to experiencing.
14122211.title: Thinking of you

141222112.content:
Stella stayed awake all through the night, maintaining a bubble in which she and Cecilia Margaret existed, a bubble outside of which time crawled. She slowed the human's aging processes, making her a few hours younger than she would have been had she aged at the rate at which her body then existed.

It took hours for the nightmares Stella could sense in her friend's mind to subside. Once they had, Stella sent Cecilia Margaret into a deep, restful sleep, still cradling her, timing it so that she would be ready to awaken when her alarm went off.

The sun had not yet risen when it did.

Cecilia Margaret sprang awake. Stella pretended to sleep.

"Hey, wake up! Don't tell me the universe gets tired. I know I'm not--I don't think I've ever had as good a rest as that."

Stella faked a yawn and stretched. "Mm?"

"Well, I'll be downstairs making breakfast once I've used the bathroom. You want some of mine or will you make your own?"

"I'll join you shortly."

Stella heard a toilet flush and a tap running for a time. Tracking the human through the house, Stella waited until she was in the kitchen, then got up and walked out.

Cecilia Margaret stood at her stove, managing multiple pans, wearing nothing but a white apron.

Without turning, she said, "I've only just started, so if you want some it's no problem."

"No, thank you, but what are you making?"

"Omelet, with bacon, four cheeses and various veggies. Yeah, I know it's not the healthiest thing, but after last night and with how I feel this morning, I figured I needed something tasty." Folding the omelet, she moved to a juicer and began squeezing a few large oranges, filling two glasses. The first she drank, while the second she put on the table before rushing back to check the stovetop.

"You know, you don't have to go naked. I do because I find it more comfortable, especially here where nobody can see me--and especially now thanks to you--but I don't mind if you don't like it. If you want, I'll rush upstairs and get dressed. Normally I'd strip off as soon as I got home, but I wasn't sure how you'd take that."

"No, that's okay. I already know--or can know, if I want to--everything about you, so it's not like you'd be hiding anything. As for me, well, I can look however I want, and besides, I could just wipe your memory of seeing me naked. I have no need for modesty."

"But you won't, will you? Nah, that's okay. If you do, you do. For all I know this is still lunchtime yesterday, and you've frozen time or something and are making me think all this is happening. Maybe I didn't have this body two days ago. Hell, maybe I didn't exist two days ago and you just made me up because you needed a friend."

"Sometimes," said Stella, "I'm not entirely sure if I actually exist."

"The universe, questioning its own existence in my kitchen? Well, all I know is that I can touch you, see you and hear you, and that I've seen you do impossible things. I'm as sure that you exist as I am sure that I exist."

"In that case, there is still one difference in the nature of our existences: I cannot cease to exist, but I can end yours with a thought. I could, should I want to, cause you to cease to have ever been."

"Yeah, you could, but since there wouldn't be anything I could do about that, I'm not going to worry about it." She checked her omelet, then transferred it onto a waiting plate. Grabbing some cutlery, she asked, "Will you join me?"

Stella followed Cecilia Margaret, who had thrown her apron onto a low chair, into her dining room, causing an identical meal to appear on the table.

The human eyed it a bit hungrily. "Can I try some?"

"If you want. It is not like what I made yesterday, though, but is rather an exact copy of what you made."

"Still, I'd like to try."

Stella cut off a piece and Cecilia Margaret reached over and stuck her fork in it, Stella's powers this time being not forthcoming.

"Yes, an exact replica. I can't tell the difference. Here, see what you think," and this time after the human cut off a slice of her meal, it floated through the air to alight on Stella's plate.

"Cool! I wonder what that feels like for the omelet," and with those words, Cecilia Margaret found herself hovering in midair, moving around the table before settling back in her seat.

"Wow! If you're doing all this for me, I can only imagine what you'll do with Mike once he accepts you for who you are."

"I want to share my existence with him, but I cannot, not fully, but he will experience as much as I can allow."

Cecilia Margaret finished her omelet, while Stella simply made hers vanish. Walking to her sink where her pans were soaking, the human quickly washed her dishes and put them on her drain rack.

She looked at her stove clock. "Okay, right on schedule. Just a few more things to do and then it's off to school."

She ran upstairs, leaving Stella waiting.

Stella's thoughts wandered to Mike again, and she caused an apparition of him to appear, one so solid she could reach out and touch it.

"I love you," she whispered in her creation's ear, but it did not respond, because Stella knew its words would be hollow.

She banished the vision as she sensed her friend leave her room. Walking down the stairs, Cecilia Margaret moved toward another door.

Wearing nothing but a strapless bra that exaggerated her breasts and skimpy panties, she opened it to reveal an electric dune buggy.

"Come on, hop in! You might want to wear something, though, just in case we run into someone."

Stella shrugged and made clothing appear on her, identical to Cecilia Margaret's but sized for her own, less spectacular proportions.

As they drove out of the garage, the human asked, "So this whole 'hidden house' thing, how does it work when we leave the area where you've put your spell, for lack of a better term?"

"We'll seem to have come out of nowhere, but anybody who sees it won't think anything of it. They won't be curious or anything like that."

Cecilia Margaret whistled. "And you just set that all up with a thought."

Stella shrugged. "Where are we going?"

"You keep asking things you could well just know," the human laughed. "But we're going to check my mailbox. It's not far, not in this thing anyway. There's maybe ten houses there, and the mail's always delivered really early. My folks might have enemies, but they've also got connections. The others haven't figured out just how early the mail comes."

"So it's delivered right to this box?"

"No, I've got an apartment in the city. I almost never go there, but it's my official address as far as almost anyone else knows. It all gets forwarded here, but like I said, my folks have connections, so that information's kept under serious security by the postal service. They do background checks and everything on anyone who might be in a position to know."

They reached the boxes, and Cecilia Margaret punched in a combination to open hers. Reaching inside the spacious box, she removed three newspapers and a few envelopes.

"Hey, do you want to drive? I've never had the chance to look at my mail en route."

Stella found the vehicle easy to operate and soon returned to her friend's home.

After parking the buggy and plugging it back in to recharge, Stella followed Cecilia Margaret back to her dining room, where she was taking a final look over her mail.

"Anything interesting?"

"Not really. Nothing about your little trick with the stars last night, of course."

"Well, there shouldn't be. It never happened, after all."

"Other than that, not much. Junk mail. Bills and statements always come at different times, though--my folks pay them but I get copies. Apparently I managed to run up over two thousand dollars on one credit card last month."

"Is that typical?"

"No, that's a bit on the high end. I need to check my randomization algorithms, see why it was using that card that often."

"I can fix that for you, if you want. I could make it truly random."

"Would you?"

"As I said, if you want. Just remember that sometimes randomness gives you long strings of the same thing."

"Yeah, I know. But at least this way I'll know there's nothing biased about it."

Stella waved a hand unnecessarily. "It's done."

"Thank you."

Folding her paper, Cecilia Margaret hopped up from her seat and went upstairs. Stella, knowing how much time remained before the bus arrived, made clothes and makeup appear on herself, and pulled her backpack and books from the nothingness to which she had consigned them the previous evening. Soon after her friend appeared, dressed in loose clothing to hide her figure, makeup as it was the day before, diminishing her beauty.

"So, shall we walk or will you just take us there in a while?"

"I think I'd rather walk," said the universe. "I feel like I could use one."

With the front door still locked, Stella pulled Cecilia Margaret to her from the foot of the stairs, turned and walked through the door, pulling the human after her.

"Cool!"
141222112.title: Early that morning

1412221122.content:
As Stella and Cecilia Margaret walked to where the school bus would stop, Stella amused herself and her companion by showing off some of her powers.

Trees flashed through a year's cycle in seconds as they passed, leaves turning from green, to red and gold, then to a brittle brown, before falling off entirely and regrowing. The weather changed, variously becoming bright and sunny, overcast, rainy (the two sheltered under huge umbrellas the universe created for the occasion) and snowy (on which the human found she could walk without leaving a mark). Stella even changed their clothing, making them nude, or in bra and panties, or more typical teenage clothing, or even in formal evening wear, backless, strapless V-neck dresses showing both Cecilia Margaret's prodigious cleavage and that which Stella had given herself for the occasion, open to the waist, going down only as far as a microskirt, held up by nothing other than the universe's will.

"You know," said the human as they walked in the dresses, their outfits complete with three-inch heels clicking on the runway which Stella had made of the packed dirt path, "if I showed up like this, or if you did, well, the school has a mild dress code for a reason."

"Yeah, but here where nobody can see us, it's fun, isn't it?"

"It is."

Abruptly Stella reverted all her alterations and grabbed her friend's hand. "Run," she said.

"Why?"

"The bus is early and even then we've been going a bit slowly. Run!"

Cecilia Margaret realized the world was blurring around her, seeming almost at a standstill, yet she felt unaffected as Stella led her on a direct route, rather than the meandering one the path took. They dashed right through flowers and trees, leaving no sign of their passage until they reached the short stretch of tall grass separating the wooded area from the road.

"How fast did we just go?" asked the human, looking at her watch.

"Not fast," replied Stella as she trudged through the grass, trampling it underfoot. "The bus was about five minutes away, and at our pace we were around fifteen. I know you like to get there with a few minutes to spare, and we'll have four."

"Four? But I know that it takes about a minute to get through this."

"Congratulations, Cecilia Margaret. You're the first human to have travelled faster than light."

"But... relativity? All that stuff?"

"Physical laws that I made. They hold because I want them to hold, and right then, I didn't want them to hold."

"And what about last night? I could've sworn I slept for hours, at any rate way longer than the time when we went to sleep and when my alarm went off."

"I can manipulate time as easily as anything else, so I simply slowed the universe for everyone but us. You needed the time to recover--I couldn't help but pick up on your nightmares."

"I have an older sister, Ursula Catherine, after my mother and her mother, two years my elder. Like me, my parents gave her a place, but she chose one in a small town. That same group that came for me came for her and got her, after only three months. When my father paid the demanded ransom, well, are you familiar with Titus Andronicus?"

"A bloody play. How much did they cut off?"

"Almost too much. She's not a pretty sight. She can communicate, but only by exhaling through her nose in Morse code. My father got experts in to install a machine that would translate that into some sort of speech. She was going to be a teacher-librarian, and was already volunteering at her town's elementary school. She loved kids." Cecilia Margaret reached into her small change purse and took out a photograph. "This was her at my age, the day she moved out."

Tears formed in Stella's eyes. "She was beautiful." She returned the picture as the bus came into view.

The two took seats near the back.

"So tell me," began the human, "what makes Mike--" She was cut off by her phone buzzing. Taking it out of her pocket, she glanced at it, then put it away.

"What was it?"

"Later. Trust me."

Silence reigned between the two for a short while as the bus trundled along the back roads leading away from the wood with Cecilia Margaret's house.

"Hey, do you want to meet some of my friends after school today? We're in a club and today's one of our meeting days. Thankfully there's a late bus. Of course, if you'd rather go back to my place I guess I couldn't stop you."

"Well, hopefully Mike will be ready to talk with me"--Stella couldn't help but catch a short flash of emotion across her friend's face--"but if he's not, yeah, I'd like that."

As far as anyone but the two knew, the rest of the bus ride passed uneventfully, but Stella and Cecilia Margaret, looking to all the world to be engaged in close, quiet conversation, laughed uproariously as Stella manipulated reality within the bus, not doing anything malicious and ensuring that nobody remembered matters as being anything but utterly normal.

Stella continued to project an image of normality as the two disembarked.

"And when you..." Cecilia Margaret cut herself off laughing.

"And then you just walked up..." Stella joined her friend.

"I've never had that much fun before," admitted the universe when they were about to enter the school building. "I've always taken my role seriously and had never thought about the fact that I can do anything I want and just reverse it all. Still, it's something that I don't think I'll do too often. Getting used to it would take some of the joy out of it."

The two parted ways to go to their lockers, and then Stella made her way to her first class.

Mike was nowhere to be seen.

Stella had arranged her schedule to share every class with her love, and all through the morning she saw only an empty seat where he should have been.

The few times her teachers asked her to answer a question she gave a correct answer, revealing reasonable but not excessive knowledge of the subject in question, and otherwise sat quietly, her conscious thoughts flitting between Mike, Cecilia Margaret and her friends, Ursula Catherine Voclain, the events of the previous night, and she had to pause time on a few occasions when she couldn't resist laughing about the bus ride that morning.

Walking to the cafeteria, she entered as she saw Cecilia Margaret pay for some food and head for a table in the corner, where Stella joined her.

"I thought cafeteria food generally sucked."

"Usually it does, yeah, so normally I just buy a bowl of soup. But they do make a good jambalaya, so I always get that when they've got it. You want to try some?"

Stella smiled and made her own appear.

"So anyway, about Mike--apart from the fact that you love him, what makes him so special?"

Stella took another bite before answering. "In almost everyone, there is some sort of darkness, some weakness through which they can be tempted to do harm. When I told you that I want nothing for the best for everything in me, that is quite true. I have no darkness myself. That is why I would not kill that one girl, not even though we both knew I could eliminate the death from reality. Mike... Mike seemed impossible. But I watched him for a time and he is like me. He is pure good. He knew, I suppose, that Lauren would probably do something unpleasant to him, yet he stayed and tried to help, where most would flee or even try to fight. That is why I love him."

"And what about me?"

"You are almost unblemished, but you are greedy. You were born to money and will do anything to remain rich. It can make you successful, and I can sense that you may become a great philanthropist, but if you are not careful it can overcome you."

"Thank you. I will remember that."

"And what was in that message, anyway?"

"Like I said, later. Please, just trust me."

Stella acquiesced.

Her afternoon classes passed much as her morning ones had. She stayed quiet, answered questions put to her and wondered why Mike wasn't there.

Cecilia Margaret was waiting for her when she went to her locker to keep up appearances. "So, ready to meet my friends?"

"Yeah, just lead the way."

The human walked toward a back area of the school, coming to an unremarkable door in a corner.
1412221122.title: Questions asked and questions answered

choices: Stella stays with Cecilia Margaret while Mike convalesces.
14122211221.content:
As Cecilia Margaret's hand reached for the handle, she heard Stella's voice in her mind.

"Please don't mention who I am. If you want to talk about the sorts of things I can do, just think. I'll know which thoughts you want me to hear and which you don't."

"Sure," the human thought back.

"CM!" exclaimed one of the people in the room as she entered.

"Hey, Owen," she replied. "Stella, this is Owen, and that's Vincent, Robert and Alan. Everyone, this is Stella."

"Hi," said Stella.

Nervous looks passed among the others in the room. "So, uh, CM, uh, do you wanna tell her or..."

"No, you should tell her, Owen," said Cecilia Margaret, while at the same time thinking, "Don't do anything rash, Stella."

Stella stood quietly.

"Well, uh, CM told us what happened with, uh, Mike. Lauren likes to pick on us, too, see, so we, uh, have our ways of keeping an eye on him. Anyway, uh, yesterday after school Lauren and his gang, uh, jumped Mike. He's in hospital now. He'll recover, but, uh, it'll take a while from what I heard."

"Do you know why he attacked Mike?" Stella asked softly.

"Uh, apparently Lauren said something about sending a message to 'your bitch of a girlfriend.' You must've pissed him off--well, not that it takes much to get Lauren pissed off. He's pretty much always pissed off."

"Don't do anything rash, Stella," Cecilia Margaret warned mentally.

Suddenly everything froze except for the two women.

Stella staggered over to her friend and sobbed on her shoulder.

She wiped her eyes after a few minutes and managed, "Don't you see? I caused this, I've got to fix it."

"No, you didn't cause any of this. Look, Mike was pretty damn frightened of you. How do you think he'll feel now? Right now you've got to let him heal. Maybe he'll think about yesterday some more, come to terms with what he saw you do. But going there now might just scare him even more."

"Then what should I do?"

"If you knew that a baby would become a mass murderer when it grew up, could you kill that baby?"

"You forget--I've known that before, and no, I couldn't."

"Yes, bad question. But here's the thing: Lauren's going to keep doing stuff like this. It's just who he is. If you want to help Mike in some way, help get Lauren out of the way."

"I can't. I am sorry, but I cannot. And how would that help Mike? It wouldn't heal his wounds."

"Do you think Lauren will just let this go at that? You're one of the prettiest girls in school, Stella, and he's pretty possessive when it comes to the pretty ones. He sees them like his personal turf."

"I'm not doing that. Not with him."

"Then you might have to be possessive yourself when it comes to Mike. Lauren's done worse."

Stella sniffled a bit, wiped her nose, then changed topics. "So what is this club, anyway?"

"You've seen my collection, you should know."

"Ah. Is this the regular kind or the..."

"We're all legal here. It's all kinds."

"So you're going to be watching..."

"No, no. We'd get kicked out pretty fast if we watched some of that stuff here. No, that's generally something we do at Robert's place. He lives in the city, only one of them to have his own place. That's not tonight, though, generally weekends. Owen comes by to pick me up--not all the way to my place, of course, I've got a number of routes out."

"I see. I'm not sure I'd enjoy those."

"Oh, I think you would. Don't think I didn't see your reaction to me last night."

"My reaction?"

"I think that human body is already affecting you in ways you didn't anticipate. Sure, you might not need to eat, or drink, or sleep, or anything like that, but other things, I think there are some things about being human that you just can't avoid."

"Oh, that. Yeah, I noticed your reaction, too--but then, you were having those feelings well before then. Yeah, I switched that off."

"But if you turned it back on, you'd be having those feelings too now."

Stella took her friend's hands. "Cecilia Margaret, I will not say that it will happen, only that if it does, it will not be with anyone other than you--and yes, I sensed that."

The human flushed.

"And I take it those feelings I sense from them are why you dress that way?"

"Them and Lauren, yeah. Lauren doesn't know just how hot I am, thankfully, while these four are going to be turned on by just about any woman."

"But you love Owen, don't you?"

"Yeah. Yeah, I do."

Stella returned herself and Cecilia Margaret to their original positions, removing all evidence of what had transpired in the prolonged instant, then unfroze time.

They spent the next two hours watching various things, laughing, recoiling, gasping.

"Why the subtitles?" Stella thought. "Given your shared interest in these things, I would've thought you'd have no need for them."

"No, they're not fluent. I am. Honestly I'd rather not have the subtitles, but they need them, so I just try to ignore them."

The late bus was almost empty, and the only other people got off when it was still ten minutes away from where Cecilia Margaret disembarked. Stella did nothing remarkable the whole way back, rather staying silent. Cecilia Margaret read, even on the walk, her feet knowing the path perfectly.

When she knew she was near her house, she put the book away and looked up.

She was greeted by a glorious vision.

Stella stood there in a glowing white robe, huge wings spreading from her back, hair done up intricately.

Suddenly Cecilia Margaret saw not only her friend, but herself from Stella's vantage, and gasped as she saw and felt a similar transformation overtake her. A glow shone from her face, concealing her identity.

"What is this?" she asked in wonder.

"This is a form I like to take from time to time. I believe you'd call it an angel."

141222112211.content:
Stella held Cecilia Margaret in midair as the human sobbed tears of gratitude, eventually managing to say, "Please, take me home."

In an instant the two were standing in the foyer of Cecilia Margaret's house, looking fully human once more.

Cecilia Margaret's eyes were red, and she winced as she rubbed at them. "Give me a sec, will you?" Stella nodded, and Cecilia Margaret ran upstairs. Stella heard a door open, a bag drop, and a tap begin to run.

She caused a vision of Mike's hospital room to appear in front of her. Noting the extent of his injuries--including a tiny fracture in his pelvis that the doctors had missed--she caused the scene to switch to Lauren and his goons beating up Mike. She knew Cecilia Margaret wouldn't be long, so she watched it at a highly accelerated rate, repeatedly, from different angles and viewpoints.

When she heard feet padding down the upstairs hallway to the stairs, she caused the scene to vanish. Cecilia Margaret came down the stairs, looking radiant with her makeup washed off, but on seeing Stella said, "If I didn't know better, right now I'd say you're furious."

"I am furious," said Stella simply, "but there's a huge difference between being furious and acting on it."

Cecilia Margaret looked where Stella was looking, and though there was nothing there, said, "You were watching Lauren beat up Mike, weren't you?"

"How--?" Stella didn't have to finish her question.

"It's not hard to guess. You're in love, after all."

Cecilia Margaret walked past her guest into her kitchen and opened her fridge, then closed it after a few seconds. She walked back into the foyer toward her TV room, saying, "How about we watch something? I don't know Mike that well, but I do know that he and I share a few common interests."

Stella replied, "Aren't you hungry?"

"No. Which is strange, since I always eat dinner around this time, so I'm always hungry around this time." Cecilia Margaret shrugged. "I'll have something later and get myself back on track tomorrow."

Stella walked swiftly to catch up with her host. "Actually, you won't. I didn't realize it until just now, but you'll never be hungry again."

"What do you mean?"

"Exactly that. You'll never need to eat or drink again. For that matter, if you do eat or drink, you'll metabolize all of it perfectly and almost instantly, you'll never need to sleep again, any injuries you suffer will heal almost instantly, and your aging is drastically slowed." Stella shook her head. "I should have seen this coming."

"Why? Did you do something to me?"

"Well, yes, but I didn't intend this. You know how I've been showing off all the things I can do, making food appear out of nothing, messing with time, isolating this house, moving you faster than light and turning you into an angel? That's why."

"I don't follow."

Stella made a bed with a foam mattress appear in the foyer. "See, there's two parts to me. There's my body, which is the universe, and there's me, which is my consciousness. The mattress is sort of like my body. I can press it"--Stella placed a hand on the mattress, causing an indentation--"but it springs back to a natural ground state, if you will. I can hold it out of that state, but that requires a constant--though minuscule--effort. For instance, I don't so much as enforce the rule that nothing can move faster than light as I just don't break it. Things work better, and need less conscious intervention from me, if nothing with mass can move faster than light."

"But you made me move faster than light."

"I did, and I also altered time around you and let you pass through solid objects. I am sorry, but it was simply easier to change your physiology to the extent necessary than it was to make you an exception to the basic laws of the universe. If I had done the latter, I would have to constantly maintain the exception or the recoil--should I ever let my concentration slip--could erase you from existence. Changing you so that those laws apply differently to you meant that I would not risk that, but as with everything, there are side effects." Stella paused. "The difference would be undetectable by your medical science, but you're not, technically, human any more, and changing you back would mean that any lingering effects of what I've done with you would hit and I would have to begin maintaining the exception."

Cecilia Margaret looked at Stella as the bed vanished, then said, "So just how slow will I age now?"

"You're not mad?"

"Why should I be mad? I mean, I guess I can't have kids now--"

"No, you can have children, and they will be normal humans. Your ova are unaffected and your body will not see them as foreign."

"Okay, so, some people would say that that's enough to make me human--my kids will be--but meanwhile I get to enjoy eating anything I want, whenever I want, I basically can't get hurt and I'll live for a pretty long time."

"Not just a 'pretty long time,' Cecilia Margaret. By your calendar you'll age at a rate of about a microsecond every googolplex years. You'll look just as you do now while your kids, and their kids, and your friends, and any other friends you make grow old and die."

"What about Mike? Or Ursula Catherine?"

"Your sister was simply the beneficiary of a temporary radical change to her body's natural healing ability. As for Mike, I did walk through a wall with him, but that was not enough to necessitate a permanent change."

"Not yet, anyway, I imagine. So I'll always have the two of you."

Stella nodded.

"Hey, wait, you said a googolplex years. Will you actually exist that long?"

"I don't remember ever not existing, or coming into existence, and my memory goes back much, much farther than a mere googolplex years."

"And what happens when the sun expands and swallows this planet?"

"You can exist in those conditions, but not much more than that. I promise that you will not be on this planet when it is ultimately destroyed."

Cecilia Margaret hugged Stella, then changed the subject. "So, as I was saying, want to watch something? Like I said, I know a bit about what Mike enjoys. We were partners on a project two years ago and while we mostly talked shop, I did find out a few things about him."

"I'd rather watch those with him, actually. Let's watch something you enjoy." Stella walked past Cecilia Margaret into the TV room.

Cecilia Margaret followed, then stopped in her tracks when she saw her shelves. "What are these?" she asked, indicating the small triangular objects stacked neatly on them.

"A gift," said Stella. "Every TV show or movie ever made, in its entirety. The storage medium is far in advance of anything you've developed, so they're useless to anyone else. Just look at them--you can tell what's on each--then think about which one you want. It'll start playing automatically. The controls are telepathic, too, and respond only to us. It's a little gift."

Cecilia Margaret found the system completely intuitive and half a minute later, she was relaxing in her favourite chair. "If you don't like it," she said, "just tell me and I'll switch to something else."

--

Dawn greeted the two women still watching TV. "Cecilia Margaret?" said Stella. "We've got school today."

"What? Oh, yeah, well, thankfully that episode's over." She looked suspiciously at Stella. "That was good timing."

Stella smiled and shrugged.

The TV turned off and Cecilia Margaret walked into her foyer, toward her garage.

"Wait!" said Stella. "Don't go out there."

"Why not? I'm just checking my mail."

"Here it is," said Stella, handing over a few pieces of junk mail.

"Thanks, but why shouldn't I go out there?"

"You shouldn't go out that way. You mentioned that the postal workers who delivered your mail had background checks done? Apparently those aren't good enough because someone found out where your mailbox was and left a little surprise." A land mine appeared in Stella's hands, clearly having been buried until a few seconds prior.

"What the fuck?" said Cecilia Margaret, jumping in shock. "I thought--" She couldn't finish the sentence.

"So did I, but it seems you--or your family, at least--have more enemies than you realized. You would've survived the blast, of course, but if it had gone off, it would have leveled everything else for a few miles around."

"Who the hell put that there? If I ever get my hands on that bastard..."

"I know, which is why I'm not going to tell you. Suffice it to say that they will only get bolder. Don't worry, I've made sure they can't affect the school bus or the school, and your mail will appear in your bedroom each morning henceforth."

"Well, thank you. Still puts a damper on my social life, though."

"Don't worry about that. I'm monitoring you and your surroundings constantly now, so anyone you're with will be perfectly safe. I promise you that nothing like that can ever happen again, at least not by your family's enemies."

"So no world peace just by flying around to all the war zones?"

Stella laughed.

"Oh, on another note," said Cecilia Margaret, "do you want to stay with me until Mike's out of the hospital or will you get a place of your own?"

"I'd rather stay here, if that's fine with you. I want to make sure there aren't any other side effects of what I've done."

"Thanks." Cecilia Margaret walked toward the stairs. "Back in a bit."

The year is 3512 AD, and Earth's once-chaotic society has developed into a peaceful utopia. It was all thanks to the help of two goddesses, Mayu and Yumi. It was a long and bumpy road, but everyone on Earth agreed that the end result was nothing short of a perfect society. In honor of the twin goddesses who allowed this utopia to become reality, the people of Earth erected a massive statue in their likeness. This monument now stands at the core the new Central Hub City (CHC), where people from all nations are able to meet together at any time. This city and the statue at its core are the symbols that all humans have moved past their petty differences, and now live together as equals.

They then looked over to the 50 foot tall golden statue in the middle of the city, depicting two young 13 year old girls standing atop a pedestal and holding hands. They each had a ponytail on one side of their head, and were clothed in robes that resembled ancient Greek togas. The duo of goddesses simply giggled.

"These humans sure have come a long way since we first came here, haven't they Yumi?" Mayu, the one with red hair and a ponytail on the right side of her head, said.

"Yes Mayu, they certainly have. It's hard to believe that we're looking at the same species that once waged pointless and self-destructive wars against itself in ages past." Yumi, the blue haired one with a ponytail on the left side of her head, replied.

"Of course, there are still those few fools who distrust us in spite of all we have done for their race... It's honestly quite depressing that some humans still think of us as 'demons who manipulated the minds of the masses into bending to our will', or something like that..." Mayu said.

After all, we are a pair of immortal beings that resemble human children, yet we have powers beyond their imaginations. We appeared on their planet out of nowhere and began advising their society's leaders in order to bring about this peaceful utopia. They simply don't understand us, and it is in their nature to fear that which they do not understand." Yumi answered.

"*sigh* Yeah, I suppose you have a point there... Still, you'd think that by now they'd realize that we're only interested in helping them. Oh well, at least the vast majority have accepted us."

"Agreed. And I think that we have done enough on this planet by now. It certainly took a while, but we have finally taught them how to work together and live in peace. I think that we can finally return home now."

Mayu simply nodded to her sister, and the two began to descend toward the ground. As the duo landed, a passing human boy accidentally bumped into the twins and knocked them down. They both landed on the ground with a thud, and they bonked their heads together in the process. The boy also fell onto his rear, and was dazed for a moment.

"Owch, what was that?" Mayu whined as she rubbed her head in pain.

"I think we might have decided to land right where this human boy was walking, and he didn't notice us in time." Yumi responded, also rubbing her head.

At this point the boy, who Mayu and Yumi assumed to be about 17 years old, had gotten back to his feet. Reaching down, he offered his hands to help the sisters stand back up as well.

"I'm really sorry, girls. I wasn't watching were I was going at all..." The boy said in a flustered and embarrassed tone.

"Oh, it's quite alright young man. We should have been more careful with where we landed as well." Yumi said.

"Yeah, well... Wait a minute, are you two who I think you are?!" The boy said as he suddenly realized the identity of the two girls he had just collided with.

"Yep! We're the lovely twin goddesses, Mayu and Yumi! And you are?" Mayu asked.

"Ummm... My name is Marcus... It's, uh, very nice to meet you two in person..." The boy said nervously.

"Well, it's a pleasure to meet you too, Marcus. Now if you don't mind, my sister and I have somewhere we need to be." Yumi replied.

"Oh, okay... Well, see ya later then..." Marcus said, sounding slightly disappointed.

Mayu and Yumi simply giggled and walked away, waving goodbye to Marcus as they went. However, as they parted ways, the goddess twins both started to feel a light and fluffy sensation in their chests. Looking at eachother, they saw that both of them were beginning to blush brightly.
